awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Durability Queries in Databases
awd_abstract_narration:
Real data tends to be noisy and often exhibits transient patterns. When using data to make decisions, one must avoid jumping to conclusions based on one particular query result. In practice, most datasets are temporal, and the abundance of historical data will continue to grow as our economic, social, and scientific activities are increasingly captured in digitized forms. Therefore, a useful way of assessing the "robustness" of a query result is to consider its durability, or how long it has remained valid. There is an abundance of real-life examples where the notion of durability can help make more meaningful decisions from data, reveal transient patterns in data, or search for interesting patterns in data that are also robust. This proposal studies the notion of durability for database queries, techniques for efficiently evaluating durability queries, and their practical applications.

This project will develop a framework for durability queries, which unifies common variants and introduces novel ones. Instead of tackling each variant separately, the project identifies underlying properties of durability queries that lead to fundamental understanding and reusable algorithmic techniques. The project will take principled approaches to designing fast, scalable algorithms and indexing methods for durability query processing. These approaches combine geometric, statistical, and approximation techniques for a meaningful balance between query efficiency and result quality. Going beyond worst-case analysis, the project researches query and indexing methods as well as complexity analysis methods aimed at non-adversarial cases that arise in practice.In addition, the project brings efficient support for durability queries to an open-source database system. The project will apply durability queries to three real-world domains with public-facing websites, as a practical test bed for the effectiveness of durability-based analysis and the efficiency of durability query processing techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Real data tends to be noisy and often exhibits transient patterns. When using data to make decisions, one must avoid jumping to conclusions based on one particular query result. In practice, most datasets are temporal, and the abundance of historical data will continue to grow as our economic, social, and scientific activities are increasingly captured in digitized forms. Therefore, a useful way of assessing the "robustness" of a query result is to consider its "durability," or, roughly speaking, how long it has remained valid. There is an abundance of real-life examples where the notion of durability can help make more meaningful decisions from data, reveal transient patterns in data, or search for interesting patterns in data that are also robust. This project studied the notion of durability for database queries, techniques for efficiently evaluating durability queries, and their practical applications.

This project considered various forms of durability queries and their applications. These include durable top-k queries on temporal data, which look for objects whose time-varying values were among the top k for least some fraction of the query interval; durable preference top-k queries, which ranks point events with multiple ranking dimensions in a context consisting of all events occurring at the same time as prior; sub-trajectory clustering, which looks for frequently occurring patterns in large spatiotemporal databases; future-durability prediction queries, where the underlying temporal data that must be simulated using a probabilistic generative model for querying; durable temporal join queries, which identify related objects whose valid-time intervals sufficiently overlap; durable pattern queries in temporal graph databases, which finds durable substructures within time-evolving graphs. The project took principled approaches to designing fast, scalable algorithms and indexing methods for durability query processing. These approaches combined geometric, statistical, and approximation techniques for a meaningful balance between query efficiency and result quality. The project also tackled specific applications, including data journalism and fact-checking, pursued techniquesand investigated directions for generalizing the notion of durability, such as robustness of machine learning techniques for database query optimization.

By studying durability as a core measure of robustness of data analysis, this project has expanded the functionality of database systems, making them easier to use and harder to misuse for data-driven decision makers. The pervasiveness of data analysis in virtually all aspects of modern life has allowed the project to put its results into practical use, facilitate industry collaboration, and attract and train young and diverse talents. Besides publications in high-impact venues in computer science research, this project has provided training for one postdoctoral fellow, six PhD students, three MS students, six undergraduate students in Computer Science, as well as two high school students.


Last Modified: 01/14/2023
Modified by: Jun Yang
